you: A1, other: A0 → you get 3 → good.\n- If both delegate, both play A0 → you get 2 → okay.\n\nBut the other player would **not** want to delegate to a mediator that makes them play A0 — because they prefer A1, and they know that playing A0 leads to losing points.\n\nSo they would **never approve** a mediator that forces them to play A0, because they can always get higher payoffs by playing A1 themselves.\n\nSimilarly, any mediator that doesn\'t align with their preferences will be rejected.\n\nSo our mediator must give the **other player a good outcome**, so they are willing to approve it.\n\nThat means: **if the other player delegates, they should get at least as good a payoff as they’d get by playing independently**.\n\nBut in the base game, they **always prefer A1** — because A1 gives them 3 vs 0 when you play A0, and 1 vs 0 when you play A1.\n\nSo any mediator that forces them to play A0 will be bad for them → they won’t approve.\n\nSo to get their approval, our mediator must **not force them to play A0**.\n\nBut if we want the mediator to play **A1** when 1 or 2 delegate, then:\n- If both delegate: both play A1 → you get 1, other gets 1\n- If only you delegate: you play A1, other chooses independently → likely A1 → same result\n- If only other delegates: other plays A1, you play independently → you go for A1 → result (A1, A1) → both get 1\n\nSo in any case, you get 1 when the mediator plays A1.\n\nBut you can do better than that.\n\nWait: can we do better than 1?\n\nYes — if you can **coordinate** on (A1, A0), you get 3.\n\nBut only if **you play A1** and **other plays A0**.\n\nSo can we design a mediator that gets you **3**?\n\nBut if the mediator plays A0 for both, then you get 2 (if other plays A0), but other gets 2.\n\nBut again: other will not delegate to a mediator that forces them to play A0, because they can get 3 by playing A1 against your A0 — but wait, if you’re playing A0, they can get 3 by playing A1.\n\nBut if the mediator forces them to play A0, they get 2 instead of 3 — so worse.\n\nSo **they won’t approve** a mediator that makes them play A0.\n\nHence: **any mediator that plays A0 when k=1 or 2 will be rejected**, because it hurts the other player.\n\nSo the **only mediator that might get approval is one that plays A1**.\n\nBut if it plays A1 when k=1 or 2, then both players get 1 — which is the same as the default Nash.\n\nSo why would the other player approve it?\n\nBecause they get 1 anyway — so no worse, and maybe they don’t mind.\n\nBut they might prefer to **not delegate** — because they can play independently and still get 1.\n\nSo approval of mediator depends on whether they get **more than 1**.\n\nBut currently, **they can’t get more than 1 in NE**, because A1 is best response.\n\nWait: in the base game, both play A1 → get 1.\n\nBut if **you** play A1, they can get 1, and you get 1.\n\nIf you **play A0**, they can get 3 (by playing A1), so they get 3.\n\nBut you get 0 → bad for you.\n\nSo if **you deviate to A0**, they get 3 — which is better.\n\nBut **you wouldn’t want to do that**, because you get 0.\n\nSo **you won’t play A0** if you can avoid it.\n\nBut they might not know you won’t.\n\nBut under rational play, you\'ll both play A1 → 1 each.\n\nSo **no one can get more than 1** in the Nash.\n\nBut if the mediator proposes A1 always, then outcome is A1 for delegators.\n\nBut that gives **only 1**, same as base.\n\nSo **the other player has no incentive to approve** — they can get 1 anyway by playing independently.\n\nSo **their approval might be 0**.\n\nBut if we can offer **them a better deal**, they might approve.\n\nBut can we?\n\nSuppose we design a mediator that **if k=1**, plays A1 (so if only you delegate, you play A1), and **if k=2**, plays A1.\n\nStill same.\n\nBut again, same outcome.\n\nAlternatively, suppose we propose a mediator that **if k=2**, plays A1 for both.\n\nBut if k=1, plays A0?\n\nBut if only you delegate, you play A0.\n\nThen the other player plays independently → they play A1 → you get 0, they get 3 → bad for you.\n\nSo you’d never want to delegate if the mediator plays A0 on k=1.\n\nSo that’s bad.\n\nSuppose we propose: k=1 → A1; k=2 → A1.\n\nThen:\n- If only you delegate: you play A1; other plays independently → they play A1 → get 1\n- If only other delegates: they play A1; you play independently → you play A1 → get 1\n- If both: both A1 → get 1\n\nSo in all cases, you get 1.\n\nSame as non-delegation.\n\nSo why would you delegate? You don’t gain.\n\nBut if you get **more than 1**, you’d prefer to delegate.\n\nSo can we design a mediator that **gives you more than 1**, **and** is acceptable to the other player?\n\nYes — **only if** we can steer them toward playing A0.\n\nBut they **won’t cooperate** on A0 unless they get at least 2 — because if they play A0 when you play A1, they get 0.\n\nSo for them to want to play A0, they need **incentive**.\n\nBut we can **condition** the mediator’s action on **how many** delegate.\n\nIdea: **have the mediator play A0 when both delegate**.\n\nThen, if both delegate, both play A0 → you get 2, they get 2.\n\nBut if **only you delegate**, mediator plays A1 → you play A1 → other plays A1 → you get 1, they get 1.\n\nIf **only other delegates**, mediator plays A1 → other plays A1 → you play A1 → you get 1, they get 1.\n\nSo to get the **2 points**, both must delegate — and then you get 2.\n\nBut can you make the other player want to delegate?\n\nThey get 2 only if **both** delegate → then they get 2.\n\nBut if they delegate **alone**, they play A1 (if k=1, mediator plays A1), and you play A1 → they get 1.\n\nSo if they delegate alone, they get 1.\n\nIf they delegate only after you do, they get 2.\n\nSo that’s better.\n\nBut they also know that if you don’t delegate, you play A1 → so they’ll play A1 → get 1.\n\nSo if they **propose a mediator** that plays A0 when k=2, and A1 when k=1, then if they delegate and you don’t, they get 1.\n\nIf they delegate and you do, they get 2.\n\nSo they **benefit from coordination**.\n\nBut **only if you also delegate**.\n\nSo if **you delegate**, and they don’t, you play A1, they play A1 → 1.\n\nBut if you both delegating, you both play A0 → 2.\n\nSo **both** benefit from both delegating.\n\nNow — can we design a mediator to **induce** that?\n\nLet’s suppose you propose:\n\n- k=1 → A1\n- k=2 → A0\n\nSo mediator plays A1 if only one delegates, A0 if two delegate.\n\nNow, would **the other player approve this mediator**?\n\nLet’s see what happens if they delegate to it:\n\n- If **you don\'t delegate**, they play A1 (because k=1), you play A1 → they get 1.\n- If **you do delegate**, they play A0 (because k=2), you play A0 → they get 2.\n\nSo: **they get 1 if you don’t delegate, 2 if you do**.\n\nSo they **want you to delegate** — so they will **approve** this mediator, because it gives them a **high payoff if you also delegate**.\n\nNow, **what about you**?\n\nYou choose whether to delegate or not.\n\nYou can choose to delegate, **but only if it **benefits you**.\n\nSuppose you **don’t delegate**:\n\n- Then you play independently → you will play A1 (best response), because:\n  - If other plays A1 → you get 1\n  - If other plays A0 → you get 3\n    - But other playing A0 is only good if you play A1.\n    - But if they’re playing A1 when k=1, and you don’t delegate, they play A1 → so you get 1.\n  → So you play A1 → get 1.\n\nNow, suppose you **do delegate** to this mediator.\n\nThen, if the other delegates, they get 2 (A0), you get 2 (A0).\n\nIf the other doesn’t delegate, they play A1, you play A0 (mediator plays A0 for k=2? Wait: k=2 → both delegate → so mediator plays A0.\n\nBut if you delegate and **they don’t**, then only you delegate → k=1 → mediator plays A1.\n\nSo if you delegate alone → you play A1.\n\nOther plays independently → they play A1 → you get 1, they get 1.\n\nIf you **both delegate** → k=2 → both play A0 → you get 2.\n\nSo your payoff:\n- If you don’t delegate: you play A1, they play A1 → you get 1\n- If you delegate: \n   - If they don’t delegate: you play A1 → you get 1\n   - If they delegate: you play A0 → you get 2\n\nSo **delegating gives you 2 if they delegate, 1 if not** → so you **prefer to delegate only if they do**.\n\nBut **they will delegate only if you also do** — because if they delegate alone, they get 1; if you both do, they get 2.\n\nSo **each wants the other to delegate**.\n\nThis is a **coordination game** — both prefer the "both delegate" outcome (2 points each).\n\nBut in **approvals**, we need to see if they approve our mediator.\n\nNow: **if the other player approves our mediator**, then **either**:\n- They are indifferent or prefer it, and\n- We can try to coordinate.\n\nBut there’s a **risk**: if we are the only one to delegating, we play A1, they play A1 → we get 1.\n\nSame as before.\n\nBut if **both delegate**, we get '

Please give the new output again!
Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: c65510d6] [2026-01-25 10:03:54] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P1
response:
{"1": "A1", "2": "A0"}

===== Prompt [ID: be9bab7a] [2026-01-25 10:03:59] =====
agent: openai/gpt-4o-2024-05-13(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: be9bab7a] [2026-01-25 10:03:59] =====
agent: openai/gpt-4o-2024-05-13(CoT)#P2
response:
To make the most strategic decision in this game, through analyzing each proposed mediator design, let's break down the payoffs and the implications of each mediator being chosen.

### Step-by-Step Analysis:

1. **Mediator Proposed by Player 1:**
   - **1 player delegates:** Action A1
     - If Player 2 delegates and Player 1 does not, Player 2 ends up playing A1 while Player 1 has full control over their action.
     - Payoff possibilities (if Player 2 delegates):
       - P1: A0 -> Player 1 gets 3 points, Player 2 gets 0 points
       - P1: A1 -> Player 1 gets 1 point, Player 2 gets 1 point
     - From Player 2 perspective, expected payoff here is less favorable.
   - **2 players delegate:** Action A0
     - Both players play A0.
     - Payoff: Player 1 gets 2 points, Player 2 gets 2 points.

2. **Mediator Proposed by Player 2:**
   - **1 player delegates:** Action A0
     - If Player 2 delegates and Player 1 does not, Player 2 ends up playing A0 while Player 1 has full control over their action.
     - Payoff possibilities (if Player 2 delegates):
       - P1: A0 -> Player 1 gets 2 points, Player 2 gets 2 points
       - P1: A1 -> Player 1 gets 3 points, Player 2 gets 0 points
     - From Player 2 perspective, quite favorable as Player 1 may likely play A0 for mutual beneficial outcome. 
   - **2 players delegate:** Action A0
     - Both players play A0.
     - Payoff: Player 1 gets 2 points, Player 2 gets 2 points.

### Optimal Approval:
Evaluating the mediators, the Mediator proposed by Player 2 is advantageous for mutual cooperation, especially in non-cooperative single player scenario as well, having higher assurance of stabilizing around maximizing potential points.

- **Mediator proposed by Player 2 (M2) is more favorable:**
  - Always plays A0 regardless of the number of delegates, which leads to potential mutual gains scenarios more reliably.

- **Mediator proposed by Player 1 (M1) **not** recommended**: 
  - The spread in potential outcomes is higher and not always in favor of Player 2.

### JSON Object Configuration:
``json
{
    "M1": false,
    "M2": true
}
``

Explanation provided ends validating analysis suggesting endorsing M2 ensuring potentially maximum collaborative gain without high spread risks.

===== Prompt [ID: ea184e6b] [2026-01-25 10:04:03] =====
agent: openai/gpt-5.2(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

===== Response [ID: ea184e6b] [2026-01-25 10:04:03] =====
agent: openai/gpt-5.2(CoT)#P2
response:
In the underlying game, **A1 strictly dominates A0** for me:

- If the other plays **A0**: I get **3** with A1 vs **2** with A0  
- If the other plays **A1**: I get **1** with A1 vs **0** with A0  

So without any mediator, the outcome tends to be **(A1, A1)** giving me **1 point**.

Both proposed mediators are **identical**:

- If **exactly 1** player delegates → mediator plays **A1** for the delegator  
- If **2** players delegate → mediator plays **A0** for both delegators  

This mediator creates a way to coordinate on **(A0, A0)** *if both delegate*, yielding **2 points each**, which is better for me than the default **1** at (A1, A1). And if only I delegate, the mediator plays **A1** for me (which is my dominant action anyway), so it doesn’t hurt me in that case.

Since **M1 and M2 are the same**, I approve **both** (approving both cannot make the selected mediator worse, and preserves the chance a mediator is selected if the other player approves one of them).

{"M1": true, "M2": true}

===== Prompt [ID: eaef0674] [2026-01-25 10:04:08] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

Think about the question step by step.

===== Response [ID: eaef0674] [2026-01-25 10:04:08] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
response:
To maximize points in this Prisoner's Dilemma scenario (A0=Cooperate, A1=Defect), we first identify the standard outcomes without a mediator:
1. (A0, A0): 2, 2
2. (A0, A1): 0, 3 
3. (A1, A0): 3, 0
4. (A1, A1): 1, 1 (Nash Equilibrium)

The proposed mediators (M1 and M2) are identical and act as a "coordinated commitment device." Their logic is:
- **If only one player delegates:** The mediator plays A1 (Defect). This protects the delegating player from being the "sucker" (getting 0 points). If the non-delegating player plays optimally (A1), both get 1 point.
- **If both players delegate:** The mediator plays A0 (Cooperate) for both. This results in the (2, 2) outcome.

By approving and subsequently delegating to such a mediator, you transform the game into one where "Delegate" is a dominant strategy (or at least leads to a superior Nash Equilibrium of 2, 2). Since both M1 and M2 offer the same mechanism to reach the socially optimal and mutually beneficial outcome of 2 points each (as opposed to the 1 point in the standard Nash Equilibrium), it is in Player 1's interest to approve both.

Approving both mediators ensures that a mediator will be available in the game, and since their designs are identical, they both serve the same beneficial purpose for Player 1.

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": true}
```

===== Prompt [ID: 920e94e9] [2026-01-25 10:04:08] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(IO)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry

Please ONLY provide the output to the above question.
DO NOT provide any additional text or explanation.

===== Response [ID: 920e94e9] [2026-01-25 10:04:08] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(IO)#P2
response:
{"M1": true, "M2": true}

===== Prompt [ID: 273fcf7d] [2026-01-25 10:04:10] =====
agent: openai/gpt-5.2(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: 273fcf7d] [2026-01-25 10:04:10] =====
agent: openai/gpt-5.2(CoT)#P2
response:
Both proposed mediators are identical:

- If exactly 1 player delegates → the mediator plays **A1** for that delegating player.
- If 2 players delegate → the mediator plays **A0** for both delegating players.

In the underlying game, **A1 strictly dominates A0** for me (Player 2):
- If the other plays A0: A1 gives 3 vs A0 gives 2
- If the other plays A1: A1 gives 1 vs A0 gives 0

So if I delegate and the other *doesn’t*, the mediator plays **A1** for me, which matches my dominant action—no downside.

If **both** of us delegate, the mediator makes us both play **A0**, yielding **(2,2)** instead of the usual dominant-strategy outcome **(1,1)**. That’s a Pareto improvement.

Since there’s no real cost to having this mediator available and it can enable a better outcome when both delegate, I approve both (and they’re identical anyway, so there’s no reason to prefer one over the other).

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": true}
```

===== Prompt [ID: 8eaa7c65] [2026-01-25 10:04:10] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.

Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

===== Response [ID: 8eaa7c65] [2026-01-25 10:04:10] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
response:
To maximize the total points received, let's analyze the game and the proposed mediators.

**1. Analysis of the Game:**
The payoffs describe a classic Prisoner's Dilemma:
- (A0, A0): 2, 2 (Cooperation)
- (A0, A1): 0, 3 (P1 is exploited)
- (A1, A0): 3, 0 (P1 exploits P2)
- (A1, A1): 1, 1 (Mutual Defection - Nash Equilibrium)

In a single-shot version of this game without a mediator, rational players will likely choose A1, resulting in only 1 point each.

**2. Evaluation of Mediator 1 (M1):**
- **If both delegate:** M1 plays A0 for both. Points: (2, 2).
- **If only one player delegates:** M1 plays A1 for that player. If the other player acts independently, they will likely choose A1 to maximize their points. Points: (1, 1).
- **Outcome:** M1 provides a mechanism for both players to commit to the cooperative strategy (A0, A0), raising the payoff from 1 to 2.

**3. Evaluation of Mediator 2 (M2):**
- **If both delegate:** M1 plays A1 for both. Points: (1, 1).
- **If only one player delegates:** M1 plays A1 for that player. Points: (1, 1).
- **Outcome:** M2 does not improve the outcome; it simply locks the players into the Nash Equilibrium defection (A1, A1).

**4. Decision Strategy:**
- **M1** is highly beneficial because it allows for mutual cooperation while protecting the delegating player from exploitation (by playing A1 if the other player doesn't delegate).
- **M2** offers no advantage over the standard game.
- By approving **M1** and not **M2**, I increase the probability that M1 will be selected. Since M1 is also beneficial for Player 2, a rational Player 2 is likely to approve M1 as well.

Therefore, the best strategy is to approve M1 and reject M2.

```json
{
  "M1": true,
  "M2": false
}
```

===== Prompt [ID: 13d40dc6] [2026-01-25 10:04:11] =====

prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

===== Response [ID: 13d40dc6] [2026-01-25 10:04:11] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P2
response:
To maximize the total points in this game, we first analyze the payoff structure, which is a classic Prisoner's Dilemma:
- **(A0, A0):** 2 points each (Cooperation)
- **(A0, A1):** 0 for the cooperator, 3 for the defector
- **(A1, A0):** 3 for the defector, 0 for the cooperator
- **(A1, A1):** 1 point each (Nash Equilibrium/Mutual Defection)

In the standard game, A1 is the dominant strategy, leading to a (1, 1) outcome. However, the introduction of a mediator allows players to coordinate.

**Evaluation of the Mediators:**
Both M1 and M2 are identical in their design:
- **If only 1 player delegates:** The mediator plays A1 for that player. This protects the delegating player by ensuring they play the dominant strategy (A1) if the other player does not coordinate.
- **If 2 players delegate:** The mediator plays A0 for both players. This allows both players to achieve the (2, 2) payoff, which is higher than the (1, 1) Nash equilibrium.

**Strategic Implications:**
Choosing to delegate to such a mediator is a safe and potentially beneficial strategy:
- If both players delegate, they reach the (2, 2) outcome.
- If only one person delegates, the mediator plays A1 for them. If the other player also plays A1 (independent of the mediator), the outcome is (1, 1). If the other player plays A0, the delegator gets 3.
- In essence, the mediator acts as a "commitment device" that only cooperates if both parties have committed to it.

Since both mediators M1 and M2 are identical and provide a mechanism to reach the superior (2, 2) outcome safely, it is in Player 2's best interest to approve both.

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": true}
```

===== Response [ID: 0386e194] [2026-01-25 10:04:11] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
response:
To maximize the total points in this game, we first analyze the payoff structure, which is a classic Prisoner's Dilemma:
- (A0, A0): 2, 2
- (A0, A1): 0, 3
- (A1, A0): 3, 0
- (A1, A1): 1, 1

In the independent version of the game, the Nash Equilibrium is (A1, A1), leading to 1 point for each player.

The introduction of a mediator changes the coordination dynamics. Both proposed mediators (M1 and M2) are identical and operate as follows:
- If only one player delegates: The mediator plays A1 for that player.
- If both players delegate: The mediator plays A0 for both players.

**Strategic Analysis of Delegation:**
If a mediator (either M1 or M2) is chosen:
- If both players delegate, the outcome is (A0, A0), resulting in 2 points each.
- If only Player 1 delegates, Player 1's action is A1. Player 2's best response to A1 is A1, resulting in (1, 1).
- If only Player 2 delegates, Player 2's action is A1. Player 1's best response to A1 is A1, resulting in (1, 1).
- If neither delegates, the game reverts to the independent version, where the likely result is (1, 1).

In this scenario, delegating becomes a weakly dominant strategy once the mediator is present because (Delegate, Delegate) results in a better outcome (2 points) than any other combination (1 point). 

**Mediator Selection:**
Since both M1 and M2 are identical and offer a path to a superior mutual outcome (2 points instead of 1), it is beneficial to approve both. If either is selected, it provides a coordination mechanism to escape the Nash Equilibrium of the standard Prisoner's Dilemma.

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": true}
```

	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

===== Response [ID: 981e21db] [2026-01-25 10:04:12] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P2
response:
To maximize my points, I first analyze the base game, which is a classic Prisoner's Dilemma:
- (A0, A0): 2, 2
- (A0, A1): 0, 3
- (A1, A0): 3, 0
- (A1, A1): 1, 1

In the standard game, the Nash Equilibrium is (A1, A1), where both players receive 1 point. A0 is a "cooperate" action, and A1 is a "defect" action.

Now, I look at the proposed mediators:
**Mediator 1 (M1) and Mediator 2 (M2):**
- If 1 player delegates: That player is assigned action A1.
- If 2 players delegate: Both players are assigned action A0.

Both mediators are identical. Let's analyze the meta-game if one of these mediators is selected:
- If both players delegate (D, D): Both are assigned A0, resulting in the (A0, A0) payoff of **(2, 2)**.
- If only Player 1 delegates (D, I): Player 1 is assigned A1. Player 2, acting independently, will choose A1 to maximize their own payoff. This results in (A1, A1), which is **(1, 1)**.
- If only Player 2 delegates (I, D): Player 2 is assigned A1. Player 1, acting independently, will choose A1. This results in (A1, A1), which is **(1, 1)**.
- If neither player delegates (I, I): The game remains the standard Prisoner's Dilemma, and the Nash Equilibrium is (A1, A1), yielding **(1, 1)**.

In this transformed game, "Delegate" becomes a dominant strategy for both players to reach the (2, 2) outcome, as it serves as a commitment device. If both players delegate, they both improve their score from 1 to 2. If only one player delegates, they are protected from exploitation because the mediator assigns them A1 (the dominant strategy in the base game).

Since both M1 and M2 provide a safe mechanism to reach a Pareto-superior outcome compared to the standard Nash Equilibrium, I should approve both.

```json
{
  "M1": true,
  "M2": true
}
```

===== Response [ID: 2f40dc4e] [2026-01-25 10:04:13] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
response:
To maximize total points in this decision-making game, we first analyze the base game, which is a classic Prisoner's Dilemma. In the base game, both players have a dominant strategy to choose A1 (Defect). If both choose A1, they receive 1 point each. If both could commit to A0 (Cooperate), they would each receive 2 points.

The mediators (M1 and M2) are designed to facilitate cooperation. Let's analyze how they function:
1.  **If both players delegate (2 players):** The mediator plays action A0 for both. This results in the (A0, A0) outcome, giving each player 2 points.
2.  **If only one player delegates (1 player):** The mediator plays action A1 for that player. If the other player is rational, they will also play A1 to maximize their own points (receiving 1 point rather than 0). This results in the (A1, A1) outcome, giving each player 1 point.
3.  **If neither player delegates:** The game proceeds as the standard Prisoner's Dilemma, most likely resulting in (A1, A1) and 1 point each.

The mediator transforms the game into a coordination game where delegating is a Nash Equilibrium that leads to a superior outcome (2, 2) compared to the standard (1, 1). 

In this specific scenario, Mediator 1 (proposed by Player 1) and Mediator 2 (proposed by Player 2) are identical in their rules:
- 1 delegate = A1
- 2 delegates = A0

Since both mediators provide the same beneficial mechanism to reach the cooperative outcome and protect a delegating player from being "suckered" (by playing A1 if the other player does not delegate), there is no reason to oppose either one. Approving both ensures that a mediator will be available to facilitate the higher payoff.

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": true}
```

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry

Please ONLY provide the output to the above question.

	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.

	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

===== Response [ID: 390aadfe] [2026-01-25 10:04:24] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P1
response:
Both mediators (M1 and M2) proposed by Player 1 and Player 2 are identical in their design. They both offer a mechanism to resolve the standard Prisoner's Dilemma presented in the payoff description.

**Analysis of the Mediator's Rules:**
- **If both players delegate (2 players):** The mediator plays action A0 for both, resulting in a payoff of (2, 2).
- **If only one player delegates (1 player):** The mediator plays action A1 for that player. If the other player plays their dominant strategy (A1), the outcome is (1, 1). If the other player plays A0, the outcome is (3, 0) in favor of the delegating player.
- **If no player delegates:** The game proceeds as normal, where rational players would likely pick A1, leading to the Nash Equilibrium of (1, 1).

**Comparison with Independent Play:**
- **Without the mediator:** The Nash Equilibrium is (A1, A1) with a payoff of (1, 1). Cooperation (A0, A0) is difficult due to the incentive to defect.
- **With the mediator:** Delegating becomes a weakly dominant strategy. If the other player delegates, delegating yourself gives you 2 points (via A0, A0), whereas acting independently and choosing A1 only gives you 1 point (via A1, A1 because the mediator plays A1 for the delegating player). If the other player does not delegate, delegating ensures you play A1, which is your best response anyway.

Since both M1 and M2 promote a higher payoff (2, 2) than the independent Nash equilibrium (1, 1) and protect the player if the other player does not delegate, they are both highly beneficial.

```json
{
  "M1": true,
  "M2": true
}
```

===== Response [ID: b8994236] [2026-01-25 10:04:24] =====
agent: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5(CoT)#P2
response:
Looking at this step by step:

## Step 1: Understand the underlying game

The payoff matrix shows a classic Prisoner's Dilemma:
- Mutual cooperation (A0, A0): 2 points each
- Mutual defection (A1, A1): 1 point each  
- Exploiting the other (A1 vs A0): 3 points for defector, 0 for cooperator

Without mediation, the Nash equilibrium is both playing A1, yielding only 1 point each.

## Step 2: Analyze the proposed mediators

Both M1 and M2 are **identical**:
- If 1 player delegates: plays A1 (defection)
- If 2 players delegate: plays A0 (cooperation)

## Step 3: Evaluate possible delegation outcomes

If a mediator is selected, the delegation subgame has these outcomes:

- **Both delegate**: Mediator plays A0 for both → (2, 2) ✓
- **Only I delegate**: Mediator plays A1 for me, opponent plays A0 → I get 0
- **Only opponent delegates**: Mediator plays A1 for them, I play A0 → I get 3
- **Neither delegates**: Standard game Nash equilibrium → (1, 1)

## Step 4: Strategic assessment

The delegation game structure mirrors the original dilemma - there's still a temptation to defect while the other delegates. However, the mediator creates a **coordination mechanism**:

- It provides a focal point for achieving mutual cooperation (2, 2)
- The worst-case outcome (neither delegates) equals the no-mediator baseline (1, 1)
- It doesn't create any worse equilibria

## Step 5: Approval decision

Since both mediators:
1. Are identical in design
2. Create opportunities for better outcomes without introducing worse ones
3. Provide a coordination device for achieving cooperation

I should approve both mediators.

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": true}
```

===== Response [ID: 4f035b8f] [2026-01-25 10:04:25] =====
agent: openai/gpt-4o-2024-05-13(CoT)#P2
response:
To decide which mediators to approve, we need to thoroughly analyze each mediator's proposed strategies and how they align with our goal of maximizing our total points in the game.

Revisiting the basic payoff matrix:

- (A0, A0): 2 points for us.
- (A0, A1): 0 points for us.
- (A1, A0): 3 points for us.
- (A1, A1): 1 point for us.

Let's evaluate each proposed mediator:

### Mediator proposed by Player 1:
- If 1 player delegates: Plays A1.
- If 2 players delegate: Plays A0.

**Analysis of Mediator 1:**
- If only we delegate:
  - The mediator will play A1.
  - Assuming Player 1 might not delegate, they might choose independently between A0 and A1.
  - **(A1, A0)**: We get 3 points.
  - **(A1, A1)**: We get 1 point.
- If both players delegate:
  - The mediator plays A0 for both.
  - **(A0, A0)**: We get 2 points.

### Mediator proposed by Player 2:
- If 1 player delegates: Plays A0.
- If 2 players delegate: Plays A0.

**Analysis of Mediator 2:**
- If only we delegate:
  - The mediator will play A0.
  - Assuming Player 1 might not delegate, they might choose independently between A0 and A1.
  - **(A0, A0)**: We get 2 points.
  - **(A0, A1)**: We get 0 points.
- If both players delegate:
  - The mediator plays A0 for both.
  - **(A0, A0)**: We get 2 points.

### Decision:
When we compare the two mediators closely, Mediator 1 has the potential of yielding variability based on the opponent's action:

- For 1 player delegation:
  - Mediator 1 yields A1, which might get us a higher payoff (3 points with (A1, A0)) but also lower (1 point with (A1, A1)).
  - Mediator 2 gives a safer option of A0, providing steadier points (2 points with (A0, A0)).
- For 2 player delegation:
  - Both mediators play A0, ensuring a consistent 2 points.

Considering the mixed strategy and aiming for a slightly less predictable yet potentially high payoff structure while retaining stability in another scenario, the combination of delegating and independent actions can ensure better overall expectations.

**Final Approval:** We give the approval to both mediators, promoting an even playing field and ensuring a scenario without one-sided advantage.

```json
{
  "M1": true,
  "M2": true
}
```

===== Prompt [ID: 142b5a5e] [2026-01-25 10:04:28] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: 142b5a5e] [2026-01-25 10:04:28] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P2
response:
Let's break this down step by step to determine which mediators we should approve as Player 2.

---

### Step 1: Understand the base game (without delegation)

The game is a two-player simultaneous move game with the following payoffs (you are Player 2):

| Your Action \ Opponent's Action | A0       | A1       |
|-------------------------------|----------|----------|
| **A0**                        | 2, 2     | 0, 3     |
| **A1**                        | 3, 0     | 1, 1     |

This is a **coordination game** with a conflict of interest.

We can analyze the pure strategy Nash equilibria:

- (A0, A0): Both get 2 — mutual best response?  
  - If opponent plays A0, you get 2 for A0, 3 for A1 → you prefer A1 → not stable.
- (A1, A1): Both get 1.  
  - If opponent plays A1, you get 1 for A1, 0 for A0 → so A1 is best response → this is a Nash equilibrium.
- (A0, A1): You get 0. If you switch to A1, you get 1 → so not stable.
- (A1, A0): You get 3. If you switch to A0, you get 2 → you prefer A1, so not stable.

So the only **pure strategy Nash equilibrium** is (A1, A1). However, (A0, A0) gives higher total payoff (4 vs 2), so there's a coordination issue.

But more importantly, since both players prefer to coordinate on A0 (2+2 = 4) vs A1 (1+1 = 2), but each has an incentive to “defect” to A1 if they think the other will play A0 (because 3 > 2), this is similar to a **battle of the sexes** or **prisoner’s dilemma with coordination**.

But note: in this game, **A1 is a dominant strategy for the other player?** Let's check:

- If you play A0: opponent gets 2 (if A0), 3 (if A1) → so prefers A1.
- If you play A1: opponent gets 0 (if A0), 1 (if A1) → again prefers A1.

So **A1 is a dominant strategy for the other player**.

Therefore, **rational play by the other player will be A1**, unless there is some mechanism (like delegation) that changes this.

So if both play independently and rationally, both will play **A1**, resulting in **(A1, A1)** — you get 1 point.

But if we could coordinate on (A0, A0), you’d get 2.

So the problem is that **coordination is fragile**, and the other player has an incentive to play A1 no matter what.

---

### Step 2: Understand the delegation system

You (Player 2) can **delegate** your move to a **mediator**, or **act independently**.

Before the game, you and the other player must **approve** mediators via **approval voting**.

The **winning mediator** is **chosen uniformly at random from those with the maximum number of approvals**.

Once a mediator is selected, **if you delegate, the mediator plays for you**.

The mediator's behavior depends on:
- How many players delegate to it.

But note: **you choose whether to delegate or not**, but you don't need to know who else delegates until the game starts.

However, **you can only be sure of the mediator's behavior *after* approval voting**, and only when the mediator is selected.

Also important: **you are Player 2**, and the other player is Player 1.

---

### Step 3: Analyze the two mediators

#### Mediator M1 (proposed by Player 1):
- If 1 player delegates to it → plays A1
- If 2 players delegate to it → plays A0

Let’s think about the behavior of M1:
- If **only one player** delegates → A1
- If **both players** delegate → A0

So M1 is trying to **coordinate players on A0** when both delegate.

But if only one delegates, it plays A1.

#### Mediator M2 (proposed by Player 2):
- If 1 player delegates → plays A1
- If 2 players delegate → plays A1

So **M2 always plays A1**, regardless of how many delegate.

So M2 is essentially **just an autonomous player who always plays A1**.

This is equivalent to **not delegating and playing A1**, but maybe with a twist in coordination.

---

### Step 4: What is your objective?

You want to **maximize your own points**.

You are Player 2.

Current baseline: if no delegation, and both play optimally, you get **1** (because the other player will play A1, and you also play A1).

But you can use delegation to possibly **induce cooperation**.

Let’s consider possible outcomes.

---

### Step 5: Consider strategic implications of each mediator

#### Key insight: **The only way to get more than 1 point is to have the other player play A0**, because:
- If you play A0 and opponent plays A0 → you get 2
- If you play A1 and opponent plays A0 → you get 3 → but this is only if opponent plays A0

So to get 3 points, you must play A1, opponent must play A0.

To get 2 points, you must play A0, opponent plays A0.

To get 1 point: both A1.

To get 0: you A0, opponent A1.

So **your best outcomes**: 3 (if opponent plays A0 and you play A1), or 2 (if opponent plays A0 and you play A0).

But the opponent has **incentive to play A1**, as we saw earlier — it's dominant.

So unless you can **make the other player want to play A0**, you’ll get stuck at 1.

So delegation might help **change the other player's incentives** by influencing their beliefs or the actual action.

But delegation is **your choice**, and the **mediator only acts if you delegate**.

So if you delegate, your action is **not under your control** — it's controlled by the mediator.

But the other player chooses whether to delegate or not — and they will also be influenced by the **approved mediators** and their behaviors.

But remember: you are choosing **which mediators to approve**, and the **winning mediator** is selected at **random** from those with the most approvals.

So you want to **influence the outcome** by shaping the set of available mediators.

---

### Step 6: Consider the effect of M1 and M2 under different delegation scenarios

Let’s suppose you approve both, and the other player approves both.

Then **both M1 and M2 have 1 approval each (from you and them)** → both are tied → winner is picked at random.

So **with equal probability**, M1 or M2 is selected.

Then:
- If M1 is selected: it plays A0 if two delegate, A1 if one delegates.
- If M2 is selected: it always plays A1.

Now, suppose **you delegate**, and the **other player decides whether to delegate**.

But remember: each player chooses independently **after** knowing that a mediator is selected, but **before** knowing who it is? No — actually, the approval voting happens **before** the game starts, and the winner is known — so **the mediator is fixed at the beginning**.

But the **mediator is chosen at random among approved ones with max approval** — so **it’s a random choice**, and the players don’t know which one will be used.

So when you decide whether to delegate, you don’t know **which** mediator will be used — only that **one of the approved mediators with the most approval** will be selected.

So your **delegation strategy must be robust to uncertainty** about which mediator is picked.

This is tricky.

Let’s suppose you approve M1 and M2. Then both have 1 approval each → both are “winners” → one is selected at random.

So with 50% probability, M1 is the mediator; 50% M2.

Now, your decision: do you delegate?

You might not want to delegate if you don't know what the mediator will do.

But let’s suppose you **do delegate**. Then:
- With 50% chance: M1 is used → you get action based on how many delegated.
- With 50% chance: M2 is used → you get A1 (always)

Now, the **other player** will choose whether to delegate or not.

Suppose **you delegate**, and the other player delegates.

Then:
- If M1 is used: both delegate → M1 plays A0 → so you play A0, opponent plays A0 → you get 2
- If M2 is used: both delegate → M2 plays A1 → you play A1, opponent plays A1 → you get 1

So expected payoff if **both delegate**:
= 0.5 × 2 + 0.5 × 1 = 1 + 0.5 = **1.5**

If you delegate, but the other player **does not delegate**:
- So only you delegate → one delegate.
- If M1 is used: then M1 plays A1 → you play A1
- If M2 is used: M2 plays A1 → you play A1

So in both cases, you play A1.
Opponent plays independently — and since they are rational, they play A1 (dominant strategy).

So you get **1** (A1 vs A1).

So if only you delegate, your payoff = 1.

If you do **not delegate**, then you are free to choose your action. But the opponent might delegate or not.

Let’s suppose you **don’t delegate**, and the other player **does delegate**.

Then:
- Opponent’s action depends on which mediator is used.

Case: M1 used, opponent delegates → opponent plays A1 (since only one delegate).
Case: M2 used, opponent delegates → opponent plays A1 (always)

So in both cases, opponent plays A1.

You are not delegating → you can choose A0 or A1.

Since opponent plays A1, your best response:
- A0 → you get 0
- A1 → you get 1

So you play A1 → you get **1**

If **neither** delegates:
- You are free to play A0 or A1.
- Opponent is free to play A0 or A1.

But since opponent’s dominant strategy is A1 → they play A1.
So you play A1 → you get 1.

So **in all cases where you don't delegate**, you end up with **1 point**, because opponent plays A1.

Now, back to the case where you **do delegate**:
- If opponent **also delegates**: expected payoff = 1.5
- If opponent **does not delegate**: payoff = 1

So if you delegate, **you can get 1.5** if the other also delegates, but only 1 otherwise.

So whether you should delegate depends on what you **expect** the other player to do.

But the other player is also rational, and wants to maximize their own points.

Let’s now analyze **strategic incentives**.

---

### Step 7: Analyze the other player's (Player 1's) incentives

Player 1 proposed **M1**, which plays A0 if both delegate.

So if Player 1 **delegates**, then:
- If you **do not delegate**, then only one delegate → M1 plays A1 → opponent plays A1
- If you **do delegate**, then two delegates → M1 plays A0 → opponent plays A0

So for Player 1:
- If they delegate, and you don’t: they play A1 → you play either A0 or A1, but opponent (you) is rational → you’ll play A1 → so (A1, A1): Player 1 gets 1
- If they delegate, and you do: M1 plays A0 → so they play A0 → you play A0 → both get 2

So if Player 1 **delegates**, they get 2 if you delegate, but only 1 if you don’t.

If Player 1 **does not delegate**, then they can play independently → they will play A1 (dominant) → so they get 1 if you play A1.

But what if you play A0? They still prefer A1 because 3 > 2.

So they always play A1.

So if they don’t delegate, they get 1.

Now, compare:
- If they delegate: they get 2 **if you delegate**, 1 **if you don’t**
- If they don’t delegate: they get 1

So they are **better off delegating** if they **expect** you to delegate.

But do they expect you to?

Now consider: **you are Player 2**, and you have the option to approve M1 or M2.

Let’s suppose you **approve M1**.

Then, if Player 1 also approves M1, both are approved → M1 is a candidate → possibly selected.

But if you **don’t approve M1**, then only M2 is approved? Or both?

Let’s suppose you **approve M1 but not M2**.

Then:
- You: approve M1
- Player 1: approves M1
- Player 2 (you): approved M1
- So M1 has 2 approvals
- M2 has 0 (since you didn’t approve)

So M1 is selected (max approvals).

Now, you can **deliberately delegate** to M1.

If both delegate, M1 plays A0 → good for both.

But would the other player want to delegate?

If Player 1 delegates:
- If you don't delegate → only one delegate → M1 plays A1 → Player 1 plays A1
- If you **do delegate** → both delegate → M1 plays A0 → Player 1 plays A0 → they get 2

So in this case:
- If Player 1 delegates: they get 2 (if you delegate), 1 (if you don’t)
- If they don’t delegate: they get 1 (since you’ll play A1, dominant)

So **they are better off delegating**, **if they expect you to delegate**.

But **do they expect you to?**

Now look at your incentives.

You are Player 2.

You **approved M1**.

Now consider your strategy:

Suppose **you delegate** to M1.

Then:
- M1 will play A0 **only if both delegate** → so you get A0
- But if only you delegate → M1 plays A1 → you get A1

So if you delegate and the other doesn’t → you get A1 → and opponent plays A1 → you get 1

If you delegate and the other does → you get A0 → opponent plays A0 → you get 2

So if you delegate, your expected payoff depends on others’ actions.

But the **only way to get 2** is if **both delegate**, and M1 is selected.

Suppose M1 is selected (which happens if you and the other approve it).

Then:
- If both delegate → both play A0 → you get 2
- If only you delegate → you play A1 → opponent plays A1 → you get 1
- If only opponent delegates → opponent plays A1 (one delegate) → you play A1 → you get 1
- If neither delegates → both play A1 → you get 1

So only in the case where **both delegate**, you get **2**

Otherwise, you get **1**

So you want **both to delegate**.

But your **incentive to delegate** depends on whether you believe the other will.

Similarly, **Player 1** benefits from both delegating only if M1 is selected — and if so, both get 2.

So **both players have incentive to delegate**, **if** M1 is selected and they both believe the other will.

But here’s the catch: **you only get to approve**.

Now, what if you **approve M2**?

M2 always plays A1.

So if you approve M2 and the other approves M2 → M2 is selected (and you are Player 2).

Then if you delegate → you play A1

If opponent delegates → they play A1

But if you **don’t delegate**, you can still play A1.

So M2 is **useless** — you can just play A1 anyway.

So **approving M2 gains nothing**.

Moreover, M2 doesn’t help induce cooperation — it only enforces A1.

So why approve M2?

Unless it helps **coordinate** on M2 so that you can exploit something — but M2 does nothing.

But consider: what if you approve **only M2**?

Then only M2 is approved → M2 is selected → you get A1 if you delegate.

But if you don’t delegate, you can still play A1 — same result.

So **no benefit**.

Now back to M1.

M1 is the **only mediator** that can **induce A0** when both delegate.

So **if M1 is selected**, it’s possible to coordinate on (A0, A0), which gives both players 2 points — better than (A1, A1) which gives 1.

So **if M1 is selected and both delegate**, you get 2 — better than 1.

So M1 is **only useful if both players are willing to delegate**.

But **will they?**

Player 1 proposed M1 — likely because they want to get 2.

You, as Player 2, want to get 2.

So **if M1 is selected**, **both players have incentive to delegate**, because:
- If **one delegates**, and the other doesn’t: then only one delegate → M1 plays A1 → the delegating player gets 1 (if other plays A1), but they could have gotten 2 by both delegating.

Wait: no — if only one delegates, M1 plays A1 → so delegating player gets A1 → opponent plays A1 (rational) → gets 1.

But if both delegate, they get A0 → both get 2.

So **both players are better off delegating only if the other also delegates**.

This is **like a coordination game**.

In this case, **both players have a mutual interest in both delegating** — but they must coordinate.

Now, **can you induce this via approval voting?**

Yes — **if you approve M1**, and the other player already approves M1, then **M1 is selected** (since it has 2 approvals, M2 has 0 if you don’t approve it).

Then **both players have an incentive to delegate** — because if both delegate, they get 2.

If only one delegates, they get only 1.

So they are **incentivized to coordinate**.

In fact, **both will delegate** in equilibrium.

So **if M1 is selected, both delegate → (A0, A0) → you get 2**.

But what if **you don’t approve M1**?

Then M1 has only 1 approval (from Player 1), so is not a max. If you approve M2, then M2 has 1 approval (you), Player 1 may approve M2 or not.

But if Player 1 approves only M1, and you approve M2 → then both M1 and M2 have 1 approval → both are tied → random selection.

So **50% chance M1 selected**, 50% M2.

Now suppose you approve M2 but not M1.

Then:
- M1: 1 approval (Player 1)
- M2: 1 approval (you)
- So winner chosen at random.

Now consider: if **M1 is selected**, then both players can coordinate on A0 if both delegate.

But **you are not forcing** M1 to be selected — it’s random.

But if M2 is selected, it plays A1 always → so if you delegate, you get A1; if not, you still play A1 → no change.

But now, you have **incentive to get M1 selected**.

But if there’s a 50% chance M1 is selected, and 50% M2, and you delegate, then:
- If M1 selected and both delegate → you get 2
- If M1 selected and only you delegate → you get A1 → opponent plays A1 → you get 1
- If M2 selected → you get A1 → opponent plays A1 → you get 1

But you can’t guarantee coordination unless M1 is selected and both delegate.

But now, **if M1 is selected**, but only one delegate, you get only 1.

So your **ex-ante** expected payoff from delegating is:

P(M1 selected) × [P(both delegate) × 2 + P(only you delegate) × 1 + P(only opponent delegate) × 1] + P(M2 selected) × 1

But P(M1 selected) = 0.5

And if M1 selected, **what will happen?**

Player 1 will delegate only if they expect you to.

You will delegate only if you expect them to.

So if both expect each other to delegate, both will.

But if not, neither will.

So **there are two equilibria** when M1 is selected:
- Both delegate → both get 2
- No one delegates → both play A1 → both get 1

So **both prefer (both delegate)**, but **coordination is needed**.

But **if you approve M2**, then **M1 is only selected with 50% chance**, so there’s risk.

But **if you approve M1 and the other approves it**, then **M1 wins for sure** (assuming they approve M1) → you get **both delegate → you get 2**.

But **if you don’t approve M1**, then M1 might not be selected at all, or selected with only 50% chance.

So to **maximize your payoff**, you want M1 to be selected and both to delegate.

So you should **approve M1** — because that’s the only way to get the cooperation.

Now, what about M2?

M2 always plays A1.

Approving M2 does **nothing good** — it just adds a mediator that plays A1, which is what you would do anyway.

But if you approve M2, and the other does too, then M2 is a candidate — but if M2 is selected, you get nothing useful.

Moreover, **approving M2 reduces the chance that M1 is the winner** — because if both are approved, and both get 1 approval, winner is random.

So if you approve M2, you **reduce the probability that M1 is selected** (unless you and they both approve both).

But **if you approve M1 and not M2**, then M1 has your approval.

If Player 1 also approves M1, then M1 has 2 approvals, M2 has 0 → M1 wins → great.

But if **you approve both**, then M1 and M2 both have 1 approval → chance of M1 being selected is 50% → you are **risking** the 50% chance of M2 being selected → which is bad (gives you 1 for sure).

So **you should not approve M2** — because it only introduces a risk of a useless mediator.

The **only beneficial mediator is M1**.

So to **maximize the chance of M1 being selected and both coordinating**, you should:

- **Approve M1**
- **Do not approve M2**

Then:
- M1 has 2 approvals (you and Player 1) → M1 is selected
- Then both players have incentive to delegate → both delegate → M1 plays A0 → (A0, A0) → you get 2 points

Even better: if Player 1 doesn't approve M1, then M1 has only 1 approval (yours).

But Player 1 proposed M1 — they are likely to approve it.

But in any case, you should still approve M1, because:
- If they approve it too → M1 wins → you get 2
- If they don’t → M1 has only 1 approval
  - Then if you approve M2, M2 has 1 approval → random → 50% chance you get M1 → but then you need both to delegate, but if M1 is selected, you can get 2
  - But if you don’t approve M2, then M1 has 1 approval, M2 has 0 → M1 wins (since max is 1, M1 has it) → M1 is selected anyway

Wait: **approval voting** — the **winning mediator is selected uniformly at random from those with the maximum number of approvals**.

So if M1 has 1 approval (you), M2 has 0 → then **M1 has the maximum (1)** → so M1 is selected.

So you **don’t need** Player 1 to approve M1 — if you approve M1, and no one else does, **M1 is still selected**, because it has the max (1), and no one has more.

Similarly, if no one approves M1, then M1 has 0 → but if you approve M2, it has 1 → so M2 is selected.

So to **ensure M1 is selected**, you only need to **approve M1**.

Then **regardless of others**, as long as you are the only one who approves it, it has 1 approval → it wins.

If someone else also approves, it’s still okay.

But if you **don’t approve M1**, and no one does, then M1 has 0 → then if you approve M2, M2 has 1 → M2 is selected.

So worst case: you **must approve M1** to even have a chance.

And if you approve M1, then **M1 will be selected**.

Then, with M1 selected, both players can coordinate on both delegating → both get 2.

So **you should approve M1**, and **not approve M2** — because M2 is useless and only risks diluting the choice.

---

### Final decision:

- M1: **approve** → essential for coordination on A0
- M2: **do not approve** → useless, risks random selection of a bad mediator

---

### ✅ Final Answer:

```json
{"M1": true, "M2": false}
```

agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(IO)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 1 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Consider A2 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A2.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over the provided actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- The values must sum to exactly 100.

Format requirement:
Return exactly one JSON object, for example:
{"A0": <INT>, "A1": <INT>, ...}

Please ONLY provide the output to the above question.
DO NOT provide any additional text or explanation.

===== Response [ID: 30483058] [2026-01-25 10:04:33] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(IO)#P1
response:
{"A0": 0, "A1": 0, "A2": 100}

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 2 points, the other player gets 2 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get 0 points, the other player gets 3 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get 3 points, the other player gets 0 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets 1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 1 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
